abstract.p: Editorial endorses Republican Gregory Camp to succeed New York State Assemblyman Alexander Grannis

block.p: On Tuesday, New York City will hold another almost-invisible election. Most people in the 65th Assembly District (much of the Upper East Side plus Roosevelt Island) probably have no idea that they can vote that day to elect a successor to Assemblyman Alexander Grannis.
Mr. Grannis, now a state commissioner, was a rare reformer, but there was not a hint of reformist sentiment among the handful of Democrats bigwigs who picked the Democratic candidate to replace him.
Given Democratic dominance in the Assembly, a thoughtful Republican like Mr. Camp can only improve the discourse and perhaps even the output in Albany.

On Tuesday, New York City will hold another almost-invisible election. Most people in the 65th Assembly District (much of the Upper East Side plus Roosevelt Island) probably have no idea that they can vote that day to elect a successor to Assemblyman Alexander Grannis.
Mr. Grannis, now a state commissioner, was a rare reformer, but there was not a hint of reformist sentiment among the handful of Democrats bigwigs who picked the Democratic candidate to replace him.

Their choice, Micah Kellner, is an appealing person, very earnest and knowledgeable about the politics of the area. But New Yorkers deserve someone chosen by voters, not a few powerful politicians. And Gregory Camp, the Republican candidate in the race, offers an excellent alternative. Mr. Camp, who has experience in the law and in finance, is an unusual Republican. He is against the death penalty, he is pro-choice, and he supports gay marriage.
He is not locked into any establishment, even though he does have the support of like-minded progressive Republicans like Mayor Michael Bloomberg and former State Senator Roy Goodman.
Given Democratic dominance in the Assembly, a thoughtful Republican can only improve the discourse and perhaps even the output in Albany. We endorse Mr. Camp in Tuesday's special election.
